In this position, I was thinking he would initiate some trades; the position is getting dangerous for black's king. Black castles long next, but that really was not wise as the next few moves would prove.

In this position, I was thinking he would initiate some trades; the position is getting dangerous for black's king. Black castles long next, but that really was not wise as the next few moves would prove.
Bg5! And now Black is in serious difficulty. F7 must remain protected, but there is only one place the black queen can go to do that, and it still results in a losing position.
Bg5! And now Black is in serious difficulty. F7 must remain protected, but there is only one place the black queen can go to do that, and it still results in a losing position.
Bxe7! The game is all but over, for black must lose the exchange or be checkmated, but he still doesn't see the danger to his King...
Bxe7! The game is all but over, for black must lose the exchange or be checkmated, but he still doesn't see the danger to his King...

Nxc6!! Here he thought a while, but still doesn't see the obvious checkmate in one if he doesn't give up a piece, or give up the queen exchange. My next move will be Nxa7 checkmate, which actually occurs because black overlooks it. Playing back through this game slowly, one can see several dubious choices black made; none seemed horribly wrong, but together, they caused this losing position. I don't want to analyze what black should have done in those past moves, for he had several better moves to pick from, and my play as white wasn't necessarily completely accurate either. But here, is there something better for black than Qxe1? I'd say... no. bryanofbay, when you've learned to form a more cohesive plan, and understand positional play a bit better, your game will greatly improve.
